Examples¶

Plotly Slider with sin waves¶

 1"""
 2This a program with a slider for variable a, with 2 curves:
 3y = a * sin(x)
 4y = sin(a * x)
 5"""
 6import P3D.graphing as p3g
 7import numpy as np
 8
 9x = np.linspace(-10, 10, 200)
10
11fig = p3g.Figure()
12
13A = np.linspace(0, 1, 21) # Array of all values of a for the slider
14
15# make the frames
16frames = []
17for a in A:
18    # Each frame has 2 traces. 
19    # We do not need to make them invisible; that will be handled by the function below.
20    frames.append([
21        p3g.Line(x = x, y = a * np.sin(x)), #y = a * sin(x)
22        p3g.Line(x = x, y = np.sin(a * x))  #y = sin(a * x)
23    ])
24# Each element of frames is a list of lines we want visible on that frame
25
26fig.add_slider( #Behold! The function that makes this way simpler!
27    slider_values = np.round(A, 4), # Round to make it nicer, 
28    traces = frames,
29    initial_step =  0, # We want the first frame visible at start
30    prefix = "a: "
31)
32
33fig.show()

3D figure with curve and surface¶

 1import P3D.graphing as p3g
 2import numpy as np
 3
 4x = np.linspace(-1, 1, 100)
 5X, Y = np.meshgrid(x, x, indexing='ij')
 6
 7
 8t = np.linspace(0, 10 * np.pi, 1000)
 9
10fig = p3g.Figure(data = [
11    p3g.Line(x = np.cos(t), y = np.sin(t), z = t / (2 * np.pi)), #Line can make 2d or 3d depending on if z is provided
12    p3g.Surface(x = X, y = Y, z = X ** 2 + Y ** 2) #z=x^2+y^2
13])
14
15# Sets the bounds on the figure; this function works for both 2D and 3D figures
16fig.update_bounds(
17    # We do not specify x, meaning it will be unaffected
18    y = [1, -1], # Having the upper bound first reverses direction
19    z = [-1, 11]
20)
21
22fig.show()

Intersection of 2 planes with Plotly Slider¶

 1import numpy as np
 2import P3D.graphing as p3g
 3
 4x = np.linspace(0, 1, 101)
 5X, Y = np.meshgrid(x, x, indexing='ij')
 6
 7fig = p3g.Figure(data = [p3g.Surface(X, Y, X + Y)])
 8n = 101 # Number of slider steps
 9S = np.round(np.linspace(0, 1, n), 4) #all s values for sliders, Round this so it looks nice on slider
10
11def RREF(Ab):
12    Ab = Ab.copy() #Make copy so that actual input is not modified
13    p = 0 #Current column that we are looking for pivot in
14    N = Ab.shape[1] - 1 #Last column to look for pivots in; don't want pivots in b column
15    # Loop to put into REF
16    for i in range(min(Ab.shape[0], N)): #Loop through smaller dimension
17        while Ab[i, p] == 0: #pivot can't be 0
18            m = np.nonzero(Ab[i:, p])[0] #Find first nonzero below this
19            if len(m) == 0: #If there is no nonzero below this-
20                p += 1 #-then move onto next column
21                if p >= N: #If that was last column, then we are in REF
22                    break
23                continue # Repeat this process on this next column
24            m = m[0] + i # Get the first nonzero. Add i since thats what we started in np.nonzero
25            Ab[[i, m], :] = Ab[[m, i], :] #Switch rows
26        if p >= N: #If beyond last column, then we are in REF
27            break
28        Ab[i, p:] /= Ab[i, p] # Make pivot equal to 1
29        for j in range(i + 1, Ab.shape[0]): # Set everything below pivot to 0
30            Ab[j, p:] -= Ab[j, i] * Ab[i, p:] # Everything before pivot is already 0
31    # Put into RREF, top to bottom
32    for i in range(1, Ab.shape[0]): # First row has nothing above it; skip
33        p = np.nonzero(Ab[i, :-1])[0] # First nonzero is pivot
34        if(len(p) == 0): #This row has no pivots, and thus no row below this will either
35            break
36        p = p[0] #Get first nonzero
37        for j in range(0, i): #Make everything above pivot 0
38            Ab[j, p:] -= Ab[j, p] * Ab[i, p:] # Everything before pivot is already 0
39    return Ab
40
41Ab = np.array([
42    [1, 1, -1, 0],
43    [0, 1, -1, -1]
44], dtype = np.float64) #this makes sure the matrix is not integers
45slider_traces = []
46
47for s in S: #Loop through each s value
48    Ab[1, 0] = -s #Change Ab to reflect this s value
49    rref = RREF(Ab)
50    c = [np.nonzero(rref[i, :])[0][0] for i in range(rref.shape[0])] #Get pivot columns
51    if 0 not in c: #x is free variable
52        x = np.linspace(0, 1, 101)
53        y = np.ones_like(x) * rref[0, -1]
54        z = np.ones_like(x) * rref[1, -1]
55    elif 1 not in c: #y is free variable
56        y = np.linspace(0, 1, 101)
57        x = rref[0, -1] - rref[0, 1] * y
58        z = np.ones_like(x) * rref[1, -1]
59    else: #z is free variable
60        z = np.linspace(-1, 3, 101)
61        x = rref[0, -1] - rref[0, 2] * z
62        y = rref[1, -1] - rref[1, 2] * z
63    slider_traces.append([p3g.Surface(X, Y, 1 - s * X + Y), p3g.Line(x, y, z, line = dict(width = 10))])
64
65fig.add_slider(S, slider_traces)
66fig.update_bounds([1, 0], [1, 0], [-1, 3])
67fig.show()

Modifiable sin waves using Dash Table¶

 1"""
 2Program that draws 3 modifiable sin waves.
 3"""
 4import P3D.graphing as p3g
 5import P3D.webpage as p3w
 6from dash import Input, Output
 7import numpy as np
 8
 9x = np.linspace(0, 2 * np.pi, 1001)
10# Make a figure with 3 lines
11# The name here will used to reference each line later
12# What we put in y does not matter, as will be explained later
13fig = p3g.Figure(data = [p3g.Line(x = x, y = 100000000 * x, name = str(i)) for i in range(3)])
14# Notice we did not have to pre-calculate and store any additional lines like before
15
16app = p3w.Webpage() # This will be the webpage
17
18app.layout = [
19    p3w.Graph(fig, id = 'graph', height = 0.7), # Put the figure in a graph. height is proportion of window's height
20    p3w.DataTable( #Automatic scroll functionality
21        columns = ['freq', 'amp'], # This says we will have 2 columns, and the names they will display
22        column_ids = ['f', 'a'], # The ids for our 2 columns
23        id = 'table',
24        data = [ # Initial data we want in the table; how number of rows is determined
25            [0, 2],
26            [1, 1],
27            [2, 0.5]
28        ],
29        height = 0.2, # Proportion of window's height. In other words, this will be 20% as tall as the window
30        properties = {
31            'editable' : ['f'] # Which columns we want to be editable, indicated by id
32        }
33    )
34]
35
36#callback defines a function (editFigure) that is called whenever an Input changes
37@app.callback(
38    Output('graph', 'figure'), #'graph' is the id we put in p3w.Graph
39    Input('table', 'data') #'table' is id the id we put in p3w.DataTable
40    # Since the data in the table is the input, whenever that changes, the below function is called
41    # Note that on startup, when the data is set, this is also called
42)
43def editFigure(data): #data parameter is the data input above
44    for i in range(3):
45        # data is a list of rows; each row has values based upon column id
46        # In other words, we get cell data by data[row number][column id]
47        # since cell data is typed, it will be a string. We use float() to convert it to numbers
48        # We select the line to update based upon name
49        fig.update_traces(y = float(data[i]['a']) * np.sin(x * float(data[i]['f'])), selector=dict(name = str(i)))
50        # Initial y data at very beginning does not matter; will be overridden by this
51    # The output (figure in graph) is set by return value
52    return fig
53
54
55app.run(debug = True) #Starts the application. using 'debug=True' means it will tell us any errors that happen

Intersection of 2 planes with Dash Table¶

  1from dash import Dash, dash_table, dcc, Input, Output, callback
  2import plotly.graph_objects as go
  3import P3D.graphing as p3g
  4import P3D.webpage as p3w
  5import numpy as np
  6
  7x = np.linspace(0, 1, 101)
  8X, Y = np.meshgrid(x, x, indexing='ij')
  9fig = p3g.Figure(data = [ # Create initial figure
 10    p3g.Surface(X, Y, X, name = "S1"), # What we put into z does not matter; will be changed with callback
 11    p3g.Surface(X, Y, X, name = "S2"),
 12    p3g.Line(x, x, x, line = dict(width = 10), name = "line") # All of x,y,z for line will be changed on callback                 
 13])
 14fig.update_layout(
 15    margin=dict(l=0, r=0, t=0, b=10)
 16)
 17
 18#RREF function, which takes in augmented matrix Ab from Ax=b
 19def RREF(Ab):
 20    Ab = Ab.copy() #Make copy so that actual input is not modified
 21    p = 0 #Current column that we are looking for pivot in
 22    N = Ab.shape[1] - 1 #Last column to look for pivots in; don't want pivots in b column
 23    # Loop to put into REF
 24    for i in range(min(Ab.shape[0], N)): #Loop through smaller dimension
 25        while Ab[i, p] == 0: #pivot can't be 0
 26            m = np.nonzero(Ab[i:, p])[0] #Find first nonzero below this
 27            if len(m) == 0: #If there is no nonzero below this-
 28                p += 1 #-then move onto next column
 29                if p >= N: #If that was last column, then we are in REF
 30                    break
 31                continue # Repeat this process on this next column
 32            m = m[0] + i # Get the first nonzero. Add i since thats what we started in np.nonzero
 33            Ab[[i, m], :] = Ab[[m, i], :] #Switch rows
 34        if p >= N: #If beyond last column, then we are in REF
 35            break
 36        Ab[i, p:] /= Ab[i, p] # Make pivot equal to 1
 37        for j in range(i + 1, Ab.shape[0]): # Set everything below pivot to 0
 38            Ab[j, p:] -= Ab[j, i] * Ab[i, p:] # Everything before pivot is already 0
 39    # Put into RREF, top to bottom
 40    for i in range(1, Ab.shape[0]): # First row has nothing above it; skip
 41        p = np.nonzero(Ab[i, :-1])[0] # First nonzero is pivot
 42        if(len(p) == 0): #This row has no pivots, and thus no row below this will either
 43            break
 44        p = p[0] #Get first nonzero
 45        for j in range(0, i): #Make everything above pivot 0
 46            Ab[j, p:] -= Ab[j, p] * Ab[i, p:] # Everything before pivot is already 0
 47    return Ab
 48
 49app = p3w.Webpage()
 50
 51app.layout = [
 52    p3w.Graph(fig, id='graph', height = 0.7),
 53    p3w.DataTable(
 54        id='table', height = 0.2,
 55        columns=['variable', 'Surface 1', 'Surface 2'],
 56        column_ids= {1: 'S1', 2: 'S2'},
 57        properties = {'editable': ['S1', 'S2']},
 58        data=[
 59            ['x slope', 1, -1],
 60            ['y slope', 1, 1],
 61            ['constant', 0, 1]
 62        ]
 63    )
 64]
 65
 66@callback(
 67    Output('graph', 'figure'),
 68    Input('table', 'data')
 69)
 70def editTable(data):
 71    Ab = []
 72    for s in ['S1', 'S2']:
 73        # Z=aX+bY+C to -C=aX+bY-Z
 74        Ab.append([float(data[0][s]), float(data[1][s]), -1, -float(data[2][s])])
 75        fig.update_traces(selector=dict(name=s), z = Ab[-1][0] * X + Ab[-1][1] * Y - Ab[-1][-1])
 76    rref = RREF(np.array(Ab))
 77    c = []
 78    for i in range(rref.shape[0]):
 79        nz = np.nonzero(rref[i, :])[0]
 80        if len(nz):
 81            c.append(nz[0])
 82    if (len(c) == 2):
 83        if 0 not in c: #x is free variable
 84            x = np.array([0, 1])
 85            y = np.ones_like(x) * rref[0, -1]
 86            z = np.ones_like(x) * rref[1, -1]
 87        elif 1 not in c: #y is free variable
 88            y = np.array([0, 1])
 89            x = rref[0, -1] - rref[0, 1] * y
 90            z = np.ones_like(x) * rref[1, -1]
 91        else: #z is free variable
 92            z_lower = []
 93            z_upper = []
 94            for i in range(2):
 95                if rref[i, 2] > 0:
 96                    z_lower.append((rref[i, -1] - 1) / rref[i, 2])
 97                    z_upper.append(rref[i, -1] / rref[i, 2])
 98                elif rref[i, 2] < 0:
 99                    z_upper.append((rref[i, -1] - 1) / rref[i, 2])
100                    z_lower.append(rref[i, -1] / rref[i, 2])
101            z = np.array([max(z_lower), min(z_upper)])
102            x = rref[0, -1] - rref[0, 2] * z
103            y = rref[1, -1] - rref[1, 2] * z
104        if np.all((x >= 0) & (x <= 1) & (y >= 0) & (y <= 1)):
105            fig.update_traces(selector=dict(name="line"), x = x, y = y, z = z, visible = True)
106            return fig
107    fig.update_traces(selector=dict(name="line"), visible = False)
108    return fig
109
110app.run(debug=True)

Text rendered fancily and on graph¶

 1import P3D.webpage as p3w
 2import P3D.graphing as p3g
 3import plotly.graph_objects as go
 4import numpy as np
 5from dash import Input, Output
 6
 7x = np.linspace(-1, 1, 101)
 8fig = p3g.Figure(data = p3g.Line(x = x, y = x))
 9
10app = p3w.Webpage()
11textarea = p3w.TextArea(value = 'x^2', id = 'rawInput', height = 0.1)
12app.layout = [
13    p3w.Graph(fig, id = 'graph', height = 0.7),
14    textarea,
15    textarea.create_Markdown(app = app, id = 'niceInput', height = 0.1)
16]
17
18@app.callback(
19    Output('graph', 'figure'),
20    Input('rawInput', 'value')
21)
22def render(data):
23    try:
24        fig.update_traces(y = p3w.TextArea.evaluate(data, {'x': x}))
25    except:
26        pass
27    return fig
28
29app.run(debug=True)

Basic Dash Slider¶

 1import P3D.webpage as p3w
 2from dash import Input, Output
 3
 4app = p3w.Webpage()
 5
 6app.layout = [
 7    p3w.Slider(min=0, max=100, step = 5, id = 'slider', value = 50, marks = None),
 8    p3w.TextArea(id = 'text')
 9]
10@app.callback(Output("text", "value"), Input("slider", "value"))
11def show(v):
12    return f"slider value: {v}"
13
14app.run(debug=True)

Interactions between buttons and text¶

 1import P3D.webpage as p3w
 2
 3app = p3w.Webpage()
 4
 5button = p3w.Button(text = 'wow', id ='b') #Changing 'wow' will change text on button
 6app.layout = [
 7    button,
 8    p3w.TextArea('bee', id='1'),
 9    p3w.TextArea('boo', id='2'),
10    p3w.TextArea('bro', id='3'),
11    p3w.TextArea('ble', id='4')
12]
13
14#function for on_click
15def funny(n_clicks, text3, text4): #n_clicks is always first argument, then other_inputs, then states
16    return f"{n_clicks}, wow!", f"{text3} or {text4}" #outputs in order
17
18button.on_click(
19    app = app, 
20    func = funny, 
21    outputs = [['1', 'value'], ['2', 'value']], 
22    other_inputs = [['3', 'value']], 
23    states = [['4', 'value']], 
24    starting_call = False #Setting this to true will cause the on_click function to be triggered on page load
25)
26
27app.run(debug=True)

Interactions between buttons and text, with interval updates¶

 1import P3D.webpage as p3w
 2from dash import Input, Output
 3import numpy as np
 4
 5app = p3w.Webpage()
 6
 7interval = p3w.Interval(app, id='int', ms = 500, value = 5, step = 3)
 8button = p3w.Button('Set to 5', id = 'btn')
 9app.layout = [
10    interval, interval.value, #Notice that both interval and its value need to be in layout
11    p3w.TextArea('bee', id='1'),
12    p3w.TextArea('boo', id='2'),
13    p3w.TextArea('bro', id='3'),
14    p3w.TextArea('ble', id='4'),
15    button,
16    p3w.Slider(-5, 5, 3, step = 0.01, id='slider', marks = {i: str(i) for i in np.linspace(-5, 5, 21)})
17]
18
19#function for on_tick
20def funny(value, text3, text4): #value is always first argument, then other_inputs, then states
21    return f"{np.round(value, 5)}, wow!", f"{text3} or {text4}" #outputs in order
22            #np.round is used to deal with slight errors in floats by rounding to 5 decimal places
23            #If you are curious, remove it, and and then let the page run while slowly changing the slider
24            #You will see values that show the floating point error
25
26interval.on_tick(
27    app = app,
28    func = funny, 
29    outputs = [['1', 'value'], ['2', 'value']], 
30    other_inputs = [['3', 'value']], 
31    states = [['4', 'value']], 
32    starting_call = True #Setting this to true will cause the on_click function to be triggered on page load
33)
34
35#This makes it so that when the button is clicked, the value in interval is set to 5
36def click(n_clicks):
37    return 5
38button.on_click(app, func = click, outputs = [[interval.value_id, 'data']])
39#Notice that to update the value, we cannot update interval.value directly for immediate updates
40#We have to use callbacks with interval.value_id
41
42#this callback sets the step of the interval to be equal to the value of the slider
43@app.callback(Input("slider", "value"))
44def stepper(v):
45    interval.step = v
46
47
48
49app.run(debug=True)

Basic example of being able to upload a file¶

 1import P3D.webpage as p3w
 2from dash import html
 3
 4app = p3w.Webpage()
 5
 6upload = p3w.Upload(id = 'upload-data', height = 0.1, multiple=False)
 7app.layout= [
 8    upload,
 9    html.Div(id ='text')
10]
11def use_file(contents, filename, last_modified):
12    return f'The file \'{filename}\' was last updated {last_modified} seconds after 1970'
13    
14upload.on_upload(app, use_file, outputs = [['text', 'children']])
15
16
17app.run(debug = True)
